fields.description: Determine mechanisms necessary for the protection of sensitive data stored in the centralized cache.

comments.body: I'm OK with doing encryption-decryption in our app. That is the only way to ensure it is encrypted over the wire. I'll investigate encryption support in the caching client library. Otherwise, we can do our own, but likely we'll have to deal with export restrictions in any case.
I was thinking about the use of SSL on the memcached connection. I ran into this blog which is now a little dated, but it has some tips: http://blog.couchbase.com/memcached-security
It looks like enabling SASL in memcached would require recompiling memcached from source.
[~dkavanagh]: Could you elaborate why we are considering storing sensitive data in memcached?

[~kgill], pls refer to EUCA-1080.
I have time now, so I'll look at the encryption beaker.session uses and see if we can do same for our file_cache. We can always bail on using the cache for these objects if it adds too much complexity or doubt. But, I'd rather fully understand the issues before simply bailing.
Now, that's not the only potentially sensitive info. Any user info (like the image list) could be considered sensitive as well. We may decide to cache more information in the future to lessen the load on the CLC and improve user responsiveness. We should address the security concerns head-on.

more comments on security. I found this link which indicates we probably won't be able to use SSL on the connection to memcached: https://bugs.launchpad.net/libmemcached/+bug/1293813

Localhost binding would be fine, but we need (or ought to) support configurations with more than 1 console server and a common memcached server.

We can bail on storing creds in the cache (even for a short time), but I feel that enabling encryption would help all around since we can't secure the connection. The task then becomes key mgmt.

Yes, if we insist on storing highly sensitive data in the cache, encryption and its implication (e.g., who needs to know the keys and how they are distributed) is the next step to explore. In addition to that, we should either explore binding to localhost or SASL, to restrict access to memcached (and encrypted data).

Let me ask about the implications of SASL and encryption. I assume we'd either have encryption keys in code or config, so that means they are plain text for someone with access to the machine hosting the console to view. I assume the same would be true for any SASL password? This also means the SASL user must be configured for memcached to allow us to authenticate the connection. We also must use a client library that supports this (libmemcached and pylibmc do support it in older versions we can use), and you mentioned that memcached would need to be re-compiled for SASL as well. The biggest hurdle here is re-building memcached since we'd need to package it ourselves.
Just did more digging and it looks like the 3rd memcached client we haven't tried yet does support SASL. Not sure if dogpile.cache support SASL via pylibmc even though the library claims to support SASL.

Yes, the encryption key would be stored on a filesystem and be accessible to console (and root). SASL credentials will be stored by saslpasswd2 to some kind of data store (/etc/sasldb2?) and be accessible to the console. It's not clear to me what SASL authentication modes are supported from memcached. I suspect it's PLAIN (but hopefully others?), which is not very secure without encryption on the wire.

I've built memcached with --enable-sasl, easy.
I've been having trouble with auth. Build the sasl tools from source to replace the older version on my Mac. Only by running "sudo" can I actually get the sasldblistusers2 to show the user w/ pass I created using saslpasswd2.
It looks like pylibmc does support sasl auth with username/pass.

[~dkavanagh], I assume that the PLAIN authentication mechanism is used to authenticate with username/pass (should be possible to check on the wire or hopefully in the logs). Is it possible to test if memcached supports any other SASL mechanisms?
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Authentication_and_Security_Layer#SASL_mechanisms
For example, SKEY?

[~dkavanagh], is there a resolution on storing sensitive data (namely keypair data and security credentials prior to user download) in memcached? I believe a solution for moving the data from memcached was discussed in the context of GUI-1080, but AFAIK there was no decision made on whether sensitive data stays in memcached.

To secure memcached:
- if sensitive data is stored in memcached, encryption of data + access control mechanisms (localhost binding or SASL) are needed
- if sensitive data is not stored in memcached, access control mechanisms are needed (localhost binding or SASL)

Open questions:
- complexity of caching sensitive data outside of memcached vs sensitive data encryption in memcached and key distribution/management
- localhost binding, is it architecturally acceptable?
- SASL authentication mechanisms supported by memcached

[~rusvika] I'm fine if we continue to use the session cookie to store those sensitive files (keypair and credentials) prior to user download. It sounds like that is much simpler for security.
I'm working on SASL again for memcached since our client library supports that. Trick is getting memcached built with SASL support. I don't think we can use localhost binding since that doesn't allow for the console to scale out. In that scenario, we must support memcached on one host and several console servers on different hosts using that single memcached instance.
For 4.1, we are only storing public image sets, instance type defs and availability zones in the cache. These don't see like sensitive things. Can we defer encryption (and SASL) for 4.1? I realize we'd need to take these steps if we start storing user-specific data, which we will want to at some point (I assume).

I just remembered, we're also storing images the user owns or has shared with them. That could be considered sensitive (but not on the same level as credentials or private key).
